awd_titl_txt: Rapid colorimetric detection of biomarkers via catalytic disassembly of gold nanoparticle aggregates
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Lee, Jeunghoon
Proposal No: 1706065 
One of the challenges for medical science is to develop low-cost, point-of-care diagnostic tools for diseases.  This research project involves developing new, high sensitivity approaches to detect key biological molecules that are markers for disease states.  The mechanism for sensing is based upon the disassembly of gold nanoparticle (particles that have diameters on the order of nanometers) aggregates held together by DNA strands.  The proposed approach provides key advantages to overcome the challenges of conventional color-based sensing technologies that utilize nanoparticle aggregation.  One advantage is that the disassembly mechanism should be less prone to false positives.  Another is the fact that the surfaces of the nanoparticles can be functionalized with different special recognition molecules that can target different types of diseases.  If successful, the proposed method will result in an easy-to-read color change, similar to a pregnancy test, for low-cost point-of-care cancer diagnostics, among many other diseases. 

The proposed research focuses on creating a colorimetric sensing system driven by disassembly of gold nanoparticle (AuNP) aggregates that can significantly increase the speed and the sensitivity of biosensing compared to those based on AuNP aggregation. While colorimetric sensing based on AuNP aggregation is very promising as a low-cost, point-of-care diagnostic tool, adoption of this approach has been hindered by slow speed and limited sensitivity due to the inherently slow diffusion of AuNP-bound DNA strands and the size of aggregates required for visible changes in optical properties. A colorimetric sensing system based on the disassembly of AuNP aggregates is a potential solution to address both speed and sensitivity. A DNA reaction network, which is a mixture of DNA strands programmed to undergo cascading strand displacement reactions, is capable of signal amplification. The proposed effort will integrate DNA reaction networks with AuNP disassembly to achieve high sensitivity in biosensing. The proposed research consists of developing and optimizing AuNP disassembly process, maximizing sensitivity and specificity by minimizing DNA reaction network leakage, and designing and testing aptamer transducer for detecting a wider variety of biomolecules. This research will significantly improve the performance and broaden the utility of AuNP-based colorimetric sensing systems in biomedical applications. The proposed research will make DNA reaction networks competitive with immunoassays, and promote interdisciplinary research between physical sciences and engineering that involves underrepresented populations, such as women, minority, first-generation, and non-traditional students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Colorimetric detection of biomolecules using gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) could provide a way for low-cost early detection of disease because such sensors produce a color change as the output signal that can be detected rapidly without the need for expensive instrumentation. Through integration of AuNP-based colorimetric sensors with DNA reaction networks and DNA aptamers, sensors capable of detecting a wide variety of biomolecular targets with high sensitivity can be created. Conventional AuNP-based colorimetric sensors that operate through aggregation of AuNPs have inherent detection limits, which can be overcome by using the disassembly of AuNPs as a signal producing mechanism.

 

The goals of research carried out under NSF CBET 1706065 were 1) to create a biosensor based on rapid disassembly of gold nanoparticle (AuNP) aggregates via catalytic/autocatalytic DNA reaction networks in response to specific targets, 2) to minimize leakage reactions of catalytic/autocatalytic DNA reaction networks for improving the sensitivity of the biosensor, and 3) to create aptamer transducer networks that can be interfaced with the biosensor to detect a wider variety of biomarkers.

 

Through the work supported by the NSF CBET award, we were able to demonstrate detection of very low concentrations of DNA targets, as low as 16 pM concentration (3.2 fmol in 200 mL) within 2 hrs, which was a significant improvement of our previous work that utilized AuNP aggregation as the detection mechanism.

 

We also designed modified fuels and interference strands for suppressing the leakage of DNA reaction network amplifiers. We found that mutual availability is a predictive tool for assessing the leakage reduction, and this design principle can be applied to reduce the cost and time required for design of various other DNA reaction networks. This result provided an insight toward leakage suppression mechanism via minimizing transient hybridization between the network substrate and the fuel strand.

 

In addition, we designed and tested modular aptamer transducers capable of detecting adenosine. Due to their modular design, the aptamer transducers can be customized for integration with downstream DNA networks, which was demonstrated by successful integration with two separate DNA amplifier networks resulting in 4-5 times improvement of adenosine detection limits. This system will enable aptamer-based biosensing to be coupled directly with DNA-based amplification and computations tools for enhanced sensing capabilities.

 

The work resulted in 2 publications with 1-2 more publications planned. The award also contributed to the training of three graduate students (2 Ph.D. and 1 M.S), nine undergraduate students, and two high school students. Of these students, one graduate student, five undergraduate students, and one high school student were female. We performed nanotechnology and DNA-related demonstrations for Boise State University students, selected Idaho high school students through Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars workshop, and general public (Chemistry demo show) in order to boost their interest and understanding in nanobiotechnology and STEM fields.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2021
Modified by: Jeunghoon Lee
